Veteran: White listing.

Veteran: Simply put, white listing. Everything in the organ-organization should be accounted for. On the military side we have uh, an L-dif, now I'm not referring to the same L-dif that's in active directory.

Veteran: Each unit, uh that is uh, issued their server stack for their mission command processing, also comes with a disk full of "these are your IPs. This is everything you're gonna have. This is also everybody else that's on the entirety of the network."

Veteran: But the way I equate this to uh, both civilians and soldiers, is, is that you have to understand your vectors of attack. If you live in a house, every window, every door, is a possible threat. One person, coming to the door, trying to pick your lock, is a DOS.
Veteran: Ten people come to your house, and one goes to each door, each window that you have, that-that's a distributed DOS.

Veteran: And if we do what we can do white list, "Hey! That guy's not supposed to be at that window. Hey! That guy's not supposed to be at that door." We know what's going on, that's a white list. But we see one of our family members come to the house, let em on in, because we know.

Veteran: But if we have so many people rushing the front door, and the door falls over, we're in a failed open state.
